conclusion: To determine whether light beam b is more likely to exhibit diffraction than light beam a, we need to consider the properties of light waves and how they interact with the medium.
Diffraction occurs when a wave encounters an obstacle or passes through an opening smaller than its wavelength.
The phenomenon is more pronounced for waves with shorter wavelengths because they have higher spatial frequencies.
The frequency of light is inversely proportional to its wavelength in a given medium.
The relationship can be expressed as c = λf, where c is the speed of light in vacuum, λ is the wavelength, and f is the frequency.
Since the speed of light c is constant in a vacuum, if one frequency fb is greater than another frequency fa, then the wavelength λb will be less than λa.
Given that light beam b has a higher frequency than light beam a, it follows that the wavelength of light beam b (λb) is shorter than the wavelength of light beam a (λa).
Since light beam b has a shorter wavelength, it is more likely to exhibit diffraction compared to light beam a.

premise: Based on the relationship between frequency, wavelength, and diffraction, light beam b (with a higher frequency and thus a shorter wavelength) is more likely to exhibit diffraction than light beam a.
conclusion: Yes, light beam b is more likely to exhibit diffraction than light beam a.
